snippet.textDisplay: Years ago I used to do forensics of floppy disks produced in duplicators my company built. I used the ferro-fluid directly on the "cookie" and could diagnose many kinds of malfunctions. That fluid was super expensive.
snippet.textOriginal: Years ago I used to do forensics of floppy disks produced in duplicators my company built. I used the ferro-fluid directly on the "cookie" and could diagnose many kinds of malfunctions. That fluid was super expensive.

snippet.textDisplay: Less messy than the rusty solvent I used to pour on tapes to see the pattern after it evaporated and left ferrous powder behind.
snippet.textOriginal: Less messy than the rusty solvent I used to pour on tapes to see the pattern after it evaporated and left ferrous powder behind.

snippet.textDisplay: In the Commodore 64 days, we used to copy tapes with cracked games. Although sometimes these didn't work, because of tape recorder head alignment differences. Which meant waiting ages for a game to load, only to get the dreaded '?LOAD ERROR'. There was a piece of software you could use to align the heads, which had output quite similar to this device. Here's a video of it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wUGTigzpjwk
snippet.textOriginal: In the Commodore 64 days, we used to copy tapes with cracked games. Although sometimes these didn't work, because of tape recorder head alignment differences. Which meant waiting ages for a game to load, only to get the dreaded '?LOAD ERROR'. There was a piece of software you could use to align the heads, which had output quite similar to this device. Here's a video of it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wUGTigzpjwk

snippet.textDisplay: Would this device be sensitive in such a way that it may get too strongly magnetized and therefore destroyed by subjecting it to a strong magnetic field, like the one of a modern neodymium magnet? No, I don't want you to try it out, don't jeopardize this rare vintage device for the sake of a question in a youtube comment. If at all, an answer like "I suspect yes" will be enough. Or if you suspect no, then try it out, but don't try it out if it destroys the device, because it is too valuable for that.
snippet.textOriginal: Would this device be sensitive in such a way that it may get too strongly magnetized and therefore destroyed by subjecting it to a strong magnetic field, like the one of a modern neodymium magnet? No, I don't want you to try it out, don't jeopardize this rare vintage device for the sake of a question in a youtube comment. If at all, an answer like "I suspect yes" will be enough. Or if you suspect no, then try it out, but don't try it out if it destroys the device, because it is too valuable for that.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey Techmoan,

I really hope you will see this message. I've been a subscriber for quite a long time and do find your videos really fascinating! I have a question for you related to Audio Cassettes: I'm currently in the possession of about 2-3 tapes (one is a rare industrial tape, the others are selfmade home recordings) that are of very high sentimental value to me since they contain private recordings of me and my brother in our early childhood years.


Is there any chance that I could make use of your tech-knowledge and have you digitize/transfer and preserve those memories into digital before it is too late and they will have deteriorated beyond restoration? I would know enough to connect a simple tape recorder to my computer and just hit play and record, but I don't know enough to get the best out of it possible, which starts with having a high-quality playback machine in the first place.


Of course, I'd be willing to pay the service as well as post costs (I'm based in Germany). Would that be an option? Looking forward to hearing back from you.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hey Techmoan, 

I really hope you will see this message. I've been a subscriber for quite a long time and do find your videos really fascinating! I have a question for you related to Audio Cassettes: I'm currently in the possession of about 2-3 tapes (one is a rare industrial tape, the others are selfmade home recordings) that are of very high sentimental value to me since they contain private recordings of me and my brother in our early childhood years.


Is there any chance that I could make use of your tech-knowledge and have you digitize/transfer and preserve those memories into digital before it is too late and they will have deteriorated beyond restoration? I would know enough to connect a simple tape recorder to my computer and just hit play and record, but I don't know enough to get the best out of it possible, which starts with having a high-quality playback machine in the first place.


Of course, I'd be willing to pay the service as well as post costs (I'm based in Germany). Would that be an option? Looking forward to hearing back from you.

snippet.textDisplay:
Being a broadcast/RF engineer I'm a lot more interested in your reel to reel set up with that level visualizer top left, I've never seen one like that. I mostly deal in modern equipment but being only 29 the old equipment feels new to me when I come across it occasionally in some radio stations usually buried in a dark back room.

I get to keep a lot of old equipment I find not to replace payment but because most people want it gone or don't know how to use old equipment.
I love modern technology but there is something special about older tech that can be repaired by someone like me much more easily than say SMT parts needing specialized hot beds to solder parts.
snippet.textOriginal:
Being a broadcast/RF engineer I'm a lot more interested in your reel to reel set up with that level visualizer top left, I've never seen one like that. I mostly deal in modern equipment but being only 29 the old equipment feels new to me when I come across it occasionally in some radio stations usually buried in a dark back room.

 I get to keep a lot of old equipment I find not to replace payment but because most people want it gone or don't know how to use old equipment.
I love modern technology but there is something special about older tech that can be repaired by someone like me much more easily than say SMT parts needing specialized hot beds to solder parts.

snippet.textDisplay:
Similar idea to the iron containing fluid they used to edit Videotape in the 1950s/1960s. You had to splice VT at exactly the right point. The fluid would show up the vertical magnetic lines.
I guess this device would help you edit audio tape in a similar way?
snippet.textOriginal:
Similar idea to the iron containing fluid they used to edit Videotape in the 1950s/1960s.  You had to splice VT at exactly the right point. The fluid would show up the vertical magnetic lines.

snippet.textDisplay: At first I thought it was a magnetic velvet like fabric, I'm a bit sad that it wasn't actually, I'm pretty certain I've seen non active magnetic-field-viewers based on colour instead of particle attraction though, but that is likely a much more recent development (I've seen one article about one such material from 2009 but it also references previous such materials in the article).
snippet.textOriginal: At first I thought it was a magnetic velvet like fabric, I'm a bit sad that it wasn't actually, I'm pretty certain I've seen non active magnetic-field-viewers based on colour instead of particle attraction though, but that is likely a much more recent development (I've seen one article about one such material from 2009 but it also references previous such materials in the article).

snippet.textDisplay:
You can buy "Magnetic Field Viewer Viewing Film" on ebay. I cannot say if it has the required resolution to "see" an eight track pattern, but it is cheap enough to pick up a sample and see.

snippet.textDisplay:
I picked up the Arnold version not too long ago (after striking out on ebay) because the Nakamichi standard cassette mechanism is a royal pain to align... It only has one tape guide on the supply side and everything downstream is controlled more or less by head tilt. Ideally you'd want the left channel completely on the tape with a few microns left over at the edge, rather than halfway off like the cassette shown in this video.

I'd rather have it further away from the edge, but then again this started out as a mono dictation machine standard and nobody really cared at the time...

They come as pictured in a small humidor that you need to remember to water every once and a while so it doesn't dry out, and the contents of the viewer cell don't seem to have the same level of consistency as that 3M original.
snippet.textOriginal:
I picked up the Arnold version not too long ago (after striking out on ebay) because the Nakamichi standard cassette mechanism is a royal pain to align... It only has one tape guide on the supply side and everything downstream is controlled more or less by head tilt. Ideally you'd want the left channel completely on the tape with a few microns left over at the edge, rather than halfway off like the cassette shown in this video.

I'd rather have it further away from the edge, but then again this started out as a mono dictation machine standard and nobody really cared at the time...

They come as pictured in a small humidor that you need to remember to water every once and a while so it doesn't dry out, and the contents of the viewer cell don't seem to have the same level of consistency as that 3M original.

snippet.textDisplay:
I started my IT career in the early 1970's in the days of mainframe computers and reel-to-reel data tapes. I recall people telling me about this device, but I had never seen one in use. The technicians, who kept the tape drives (and everything else) running, used it for some purpose, although I don't recall what. Those data tapes were 9-track and either 800 bpi (bits per inch) or 1600 bpi. There were other variants but, by far, this was the industry standard at the time. I see the device as novel but I am not sure of the practical use. We calibrated tape drives with a read-only tape that had been created on a "certified standard" drive. Thus, the machine testing software used by the technicians and the oscilloscope readings could really nail down any needed adjustments.

As a sidebar, when tapes were written upon, a tape label was added to the outside surface of the tape reel. This stated the tape name, date recorded, the reel sequence (1 of n), and the tape-drive unit-number upon which it was recorded. This last bit of information was critical because if, at a later date, the tape encountered any read problems, the specific drive from which it was created would be used in an attempt to read the tape. The theory being the head alignment would be spot-on, relative to the tape, and this would be the best chance at recovering the data.

Thanks for posting this video. I had heard of this device but had never seen one!
snippet.textOriginal:
I started my IT career in the early 1970's in the days of mainframe computers and reel-to-reel data tapes.  I recall people telling me about this device, but I had never seen one in use.  The technicians, who kept the tape drives (and everything else) running, used it for some purpose, although I don't recall what.  Those data tapes were 9-track and either 800 bpi (bits per inch) or 1600 bpi.  There were other variants but, by far, this was the industry standard at the time.  I see the device as novel but I am not sure of the practical use.  We calibrated tape drives with a read-only tape that had been created on a "certified standard" drive.  Thus, the machine testing software used by the technicians and the oscilloscope readings could really nail down any needed adjustments.

As a sidebar, when tapes were written upon, a tape label was added to the outside surface of the tape reel.  This stated the tape name, date recorded, the reel sequence (1 of n), and the tape-drive unit-number upon which it was recorded.   This last bit of information was critical because if, at a later date, the tape encountered any read problems, the specific drive from which it was created would be used in an attempt to read the tape.  The theory being the head alignment would be spot-on, relative to the tape, and this would be the best chance at recovering the data.

Thanks for posting this video.  I had heard of this device but had never seen one!

snippet.textDisplay: Kudos to T for revealing something I never knew existed in the audio world.  I've read audio magazines since 1972.  At that time reel to reel was still quite a force in audio equipment for the common man.  Actually my first audio mag was a 1972 Tape Buyer's Guide published b Stereo Review.  I was a young audio immersed person who had just got my first Wollensak by 3M 4-track reel to reel.  In all the years since I've continued to read audio magazines and I've never heard or seen this unique gadget.  Good detective work.
snippet.textOriginal: Kudos to T for revealing something I never knew existed in the audio world.  I've read audio magazines since 1972.  At that time reel to reel was still quite a force in audio equipment for the common man.  Actually my first audio mag was a 1972 Tape Buyer's Guide published b Stereo Review.  I was a young audio immersed person who had just got my first Wollensak by 3M 4-track reel to reel.  In all the years since I've continued to read audio magazines and I've never heard or seen this unique gadget.  Good detective work.

snippet.textDisplay:
Nice video showcasing an interesting device! I seem to recall seeing a product that was similar in results but worked differently. It was a liquid chemical or solution that you applied to a spot on the tape, allowing you to see the magnetic orientation. It was non-destructive, but I don't recall if it faded or wore off with use. I think it was for data recording tapes, not audio, but it's from so long ago (1970s?) that I can't be sure.

I recognized at least a dozen names on that Actors Master Tape!
snippet.textOriginal:
Nice video showcasing an interesting device!  I seem to recall seeing a product that was similar in results but worked differently.  It was a liquid chemical or solution that you applied to a spot on the tape, allowing you to see the magnetic orientation.  It was non-destructive, but I don't recall if it faded or wore off with use.  I think it was for data recording tapes, not audio, but it's from so long ago (1970s?) that I can't be sure.

I recognized at least a dozen names on that Actors Master Tape!

snippet.textDisplay: I use a reader similar to this one quite regularly at the audio facility I work at. I'm an audio engineer and I specialize in archiving older media formats for preservation. Many times, I will get tapes and magnetic film with minimal or no documentation which makes playing them back properly difficult. The magnetic tape viewers I have at my disposal is a big help in that regard.
snippet.textOriginal: I use a reader similar to this one quite regularly at the audio facility I work at. I'm an audio engineer and I specialize in archiving older media formats for preservation. Many times, I will get tapes and magnetic film with minimal or no documentation which makes playing them back properly difficult. The magnetic tape viewers I have at my disposal is a big help in that regard.

snippet.textDisplay: We used to have a spray when I worked for a company that made card encoders back in the early 90's. Have no idea what the stuff was called... Still produced. :)

snippet.textDisplay:
The compact cassette:
That's interesting, that the outer track on the edge (don't know which L/R channel it is) is a bit smaler then the inner track.
THAT could explain my experience, why on some recordings one of the stereo channels sometimes is a bit more "sensitive" to level- or dropout-issuse then the other!
snippet.textOriginal:
The compact cassette:
That's interesting, that the outer track on the edge (don't know which L/R channel it is) is a bit smaler then the inner track.

snippet.textDisplay: Are such viewers truly "non-invasive" though? They may be no mess to clean up as with fluid viewers, but it almost certainly isn't non-destructive. It takes some energy to excite the fluid, and some demagnetization caused to the monitored tape each time the device moves relative to it.
snippet.textOriginal: Are such viewers truly "non-invasive" though? They may be no mess to clean up as with fluid viewers, but it almost certainly isn't non-destructive. It takes some energy to excite the fluid, and some demagnetization caused to the monitored tape each time the device moves relative to it.

snippet.textDisplay: In the late 80's & early 90's I was using a spray containing ferrous oxyde particles to see the recordings on a tape (16 & 32 tracks one a one-inch tape). The particles floating in the liquid (alcohol?) would appear once the tape dried, in just a few seconds. Very handy to check if the heads were properly aligned (otherwise the first or last track would be lost). One could also see the recordings on a VHS tape (or any rotary-head tape recorder), however some king of magnifier would then be necessary to find the marks. The fine ferrous dust would have to be removed to avoid   going in the recorder - or simply cut and trash the piece of tape...
snippet.textOriginal: In the late 80's & early 90's I was using a spray containing ferrous oxyde particles to see the recordings on a tape (16 & 32 tracks one a one-inch tape). The particles floating in the liquid (alcohol?) would appear once the tape dried, in just a few seconds. Very handy to check if the heads were properly aligned (otherwise the first or last track would be lost). One could also see the recordings on a VHS tape (or any rotary-head tape recorder), however some king of magnifier would then be necessary to find the marks. The fine ferrous dust would have to be removed to avoid   going in the recorder - or simply cut and trash the piece of tape...
